document.masterDocTitle: A review of the Cetoniinae (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae) from Argentina and adjacent countries: systematics and geographic distributions

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A review of the Cetoniinae (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae) from Argentina and adjacent countries: systematics and geographic distributions

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution:
ARGENTINA
: Córdoba : El Sauce, Santa Rosa; Los Reartes; Los Molinos; La Falda; Alta Gracia; Valle Hermoso; Tanti; Los Cocos; San Javier; San Clemente; Athos Pampa ( Viana & Williner 1981 );
“Rep. Argentina / 21.12.30 / Sierra Cordoba ”, “10”, “
Gymn. cordobana
/ m. Typus / determ. Schürhoff Berlin” [red label], “1932 / 16” [green label], “Staatl. / Museum für / Tierkunde Dresden”, 1 male “ holotype ” [ SMTD ]
( Antoine 2001 );
Col. Schürhoff , 1 male “ paratype ” [ NHMB ]
,
1 female “ allotype ” [MNHU]
( Antoine 2001 );
San Luis
: El Volcán; Merlo; Villa Elena ( Viana & Williner 1981 );
La Pampa
( Aravena 1960 ): “Loventuel”, erratum pro Loventué, Fortuna leg. ( Aravena 1974 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 56–61 . Armature of the internal sac and details of spines: 56–57,
Gymnetis chalcipes
; 58–59,
Gymnetis litigiosa
(La Rioja: Los Molinos); 60–61,
Gymnetis pudibunda
.

Note 1 : Most likely due to the small yellow spots of some specimens ( Figs. 33–34 ),
G. cordobana
was erroneously identified as
G. flavomarginata
, not Blanchard, 1842.
Gymnetis cyanipes Burmeister
was not published.

Note 2 : The type locality given by Schürhoff (1937) was erroneously stated to be in Brazil , as also established by Antoine (2001) . This species is undoubtedly endemic to central Argentina ( Fig. 1 ).

Note 3 :
Gymnetis cordobana
may be distinguished from the similar
G. carbo
by its intense metallic blue shine on the sternites and legs ( Fig. 35 ), and by the male genitalia ( Figs. 39 and 41 respectively).

Note 4 :
Gymnetis cordobana
was treated as a subspecies of
G. bouvieri
by Antoine (2001) , and it is treated here as a separate species.
Gymnetis cordobana
may be distinguished from
G. bouvieri
by to its greater size, the more regularly convexity on the lateral margins of the elytra ( Figs. 33–34 ), not straight and more narrowed posteriorly as in
G. bouvieri
( Figs. 30–31 ), and the more intense blue color on the sternites and legs ( Fig. 35 ). Although the male parameres of
G. cordobana
( Fig. 39 ) are similar to those of
G. bouvieri
( Fig. 38 ), the ratio of length of apical lobes / length of the basal portion of the parameres is 0.28 in
G. bouvieri
and 0.38 in
G. cordobana
(the basal portion of the parameres is longer in
G. bouvieri
and shorther in
G. cordobana
).
